For the first few weeks after the election, the main emphasis from both parties seemed to be about "power".
 
 The democrats crowed frequently about the gain of their power, including Pelosi flexing some muscle. The republicans cried about their loss of power.
 
 It seems to me that our politicians have the completely wrong viewpoint. Ours is supposed to be a government of the people, by the people, and for the people. OUr reps and pres and justices should not be flexing power but rather representing the people to whom the power is invested.
 
 We have let politicians pervert our constitution to enable their own agendas. No matter which party they are from. I propose that in the next election we, as a country, organize and elect only independents. The unknown person who does not have that much money.
 
 Both parties claim to be for the little guy. Name one poor or middle class american serving in a federally elected position. You cannot.
 
 Both sides represent large money. Take a look at the paying contributors to the various campaigns. It will astonish you. Big money. 
 
 Here are the top five contributors to the DNC for 2006:
 
 Goldman Sachs
 
 $132,700
 
 Pond North LLP
 
 $109,296
 
 Jonathan Rose & Co
 
 $106,800
 
 Hill Wallack
 
 $100,000
 
 Lehman Brothers
 
 $86,650
 
 and here are the top five to the RNC for 2006
 The Villages
 
 $300,000
 
 Goldman Sachs
 
 $245,655
 
 Enterprise Rent-A-Car
 
 $227,220
 
 Federated Investors Inc
 
 $225,234
 
 NVR Homes
 
 $210,200
 
 Here are the top 5 industries contributing to the DNC 2006
 
 Retired
 
 $6,568,175
 
 Lawyers/Law Firms
 
 $2,766,167
 
 Securities & Investment
 
 $2,018,535
 
 Real Estate
 
 $1,245,892
 
 Education
 
 $1,199,298
 
 And for the RNC 2006:
 
 Retired
 
 $14,002,246
 
 Real Estate
 
 $5,679,405
 
 Securities & Investment
 
 $5,214,665
 
 Misc Business
 
 $4,512,587
 
 Misc Finance
 
 $2,909,640
 
 I find it highly interesting information. We keep going after big oil and defense and their contributions are insignificant compared to banking, securities, and real estate. Not to mention the retired lobby which is growing as the baby boomers age.
 
 I look forward to the replys
 
 Huck

 nah, a third party would only become part of the problem. Vote only for folks who claim no affiliation. Look for folks without the money to run a proper campaign. They are more likely better reps.

nah, a third party would only become part of the problem. Vote only for folks who claim no affiliation. Look for folks without the money to run a proper campaign. They are more likely better reps.

 
 Yes independants would be my first choice, but I think 3 parties would be better than what we've got. As it is we've got one party in and one out. With three, it would make it harder to get/keep in power, so they would have to represents us better.
